subject: Physics
expanded_description: Comprehensive study of phasor diagrams for AC circuit analysis, including construction methods, interpretation techniques, and applications in solving complex AC circuit problems with multiple components and sources.
learning_objectives: Construct phasor diagrams for basic AC circuit elements
Analyze series and parallel circuits using phasor diagrams
Solve AC circuit problems graphically using phasor methods
Interpret phase relationships from phasor diagrams
Apply phasor diagrams to power factor analysis
Use phasor diagrams for complex circuit troubleshooting

core_concept.principle: Phasor Diagram Fundamentals: Rotating vector representation, Reference phasor selection, Magnitude and angle representation, Phasor addition and subtraction, Component relationships, Phase angle determination, Graphical analysis methods, Power triangle construction, Impedance triangle relationships.
core_concept.explanation: Phasor diagrams provide visual representation of AC quantities as rotating vectors, enabling graphical analysis of magnitude and phase relationships in AC circuits through vector operations and geometric constructions.

image.caption: Basic phasor representations and relationships in AC circuits

sections.introduction: Basic principles of phasor representation, construction techniques, and analysis methods for simple AC circuits using phasor diagrams.

key_concept.definition: Phasor fundamentals: Rotating vector concept, Reference axis selection, Magnitude representation, Angle measurement, Phasor notation, Graphical construction, Scale selection, Component phasors, Resultant determination, Phase relationships, Time domain connection, Frequency independence.
key_concept.context: Phasor diagrams provide intuitive visual understanding of AC circuit behavior, complementing mathematical analysis and aiding in circuit design and troubleshooting.

image.caption: Basic construction and interpretation of phasor diagrams

classifications.value: Classification based on circuit configuration and analysis purpose
classifications.behavior: Different phasor diagrams serve specific purposes: voltage diagrams show voltage relationships and phase angles; current diagrams display current distribution and phase; impedance diagrams represent circuit opposition characteristics; power diagrams illustrate real and reactive power relationships; series circuit phasors use common current reference; parallel circuit phasors use common voltage reference

examples.explanation: Step-by-step construction of phasor diagrams starting with reference selection and adding components according to their phase relationships

image.caption: Construction methodology for basic phasor diagrams

examples.explanation: Representation of individual circuit components as phasors with specific magnitude and phase characteristics

image.caption: Phasor characteristics of basic circuit elements

classifications.note: Phasors rotate counterclockwise at angular frequency ω. Length represents magnitude (RMS or peak). Angle represents phase relative to reference. Resistor phasors are in phase with reference. Inductor phasors lead by 90°. Capacitor phasors lag by 90°. Phasor diagrams are frequency-domain representations. Same frequency phasors can be added directly. Different frequencies require separate diagrams.

principles.statement: Phasors represent sinusoidal AC quantities as rotating vectors in the complex plane, where the vector length corresponds to amplitude (or RMS value) and the angle corresponds to phase. A voltage $v(t) = V_m\cos(\omega t + \phi)$ is represented by phasor $\mathbf{V} = V_m\angle\phi$ or $\mathbf{V} = V_m e^{j\phi}$. Construction follows systematic methods: (1) Reference Selection: Choose a reference phasor (usually current in series circuits, voltage in parallel circuits) and draw it along the positive real axis. (2) Component Addition: Add other phasors according to their phase relationships: resistors in phase with current, inductors leading by 90°, capacitors lagging by 90°. (3) Scale Determination: Use consistent scaling (e.g., 1cm = 10V) for all phasors. (4) Resultant Calculation: Find resultant phasors using vector addition (graphical or mathematical). (5) Interpretation: Measure magnitudes and angles from the diagram. Key relationships: In series circuits, current is common, so use current as reference; voltage phasors add vectorially. In parallel circuits, voltage is common, so use voltage as reference; current phasors add vectorially. The phase angle between voltage and current determines power factor. Phasor diagrams provide immediate visual insight into circuit behavior, showing at a glance whether a circuit is capacitive, inductive, or resistive, and the relative magnitudes of different quantities.
principles.application: Construct phasor diagrams for given circuit configurations. Determine phase relationships from phasor diagrams. Calculate unknown voltages or currents using phasor addition. Analyze power factor from voltage-current phase angle. Troubleshoot circuit problems using phasor visualization. Design circuits to achieve specific phase relationships.
principles.example: Series RL: R=100Ω, X_L=150Ω, I=1A. Reference: I along 0°. V_R=100V at 0°, V_L=150V at +90°. Resultant V=√(100²+150²)=180V, phase=tan⁻¹(150/100)=56.3°. Diagram shows V leading I by 56.3°.
principles.analogy: Like a clock with multiple hands - each hand (phasor) rotates at the same speed (frequency) but points in different directions (phases); we can analyze their relationships at any instant by looking at their positions relative to each other

image.caption: Systematic construction methods for phasor diagrams

worked_examples.title: Basic Phasor Diagram Construction
worked_examples.problem: Construct phasor diagrams for: (a) Pure resistor: R=50Ω, I=2A, (b) Pure inductor: X_L=80Ω, I=1.5A, (c) Pure capacitor: X_C=120Ω, I=0.8A, (d) Series RL: R=30Ω, X_L=40Ω, I=3A.

step_by_step.explanation: Current reference along 0°. V_R = I×R = 2×50 = 100V in phase with current. Single phasor at 0°.
Current reference along 0°. V_L = I×X_L = 1.5×80 = 120V leading current by 90°. Phasor at +90°.
Current reference along 0°. V_C = I×X_C = 0.8×120 = 96V lagging current by 90°. Phasor at -90°.
Current reference along 0°. V_R = 3×30 = 90V at 0°. V_L = 3×40 = 120V at +90°. Resultant V = √(90²+120²)=150V. Phase = tan⁻¹(120/90)=53.1°.
Draw I horizontally right. Add V_R in same direction. Add V_L vertically up. Draw resultant from origin to tip of V_L.
Series RL: voltage leads current by 53.1°, circuit is inductive.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Resistor: single 100V phasor at 0°; (b) Inductor: 120V at +90°; (c) Capacitor: 96V at -90°; (d) Series RL: V=150V at 53.1°. Diagrams show characteristic phase relationships.

worked_examples.title: Phasor Addition and Resultant Calculation
worked_examples.problem: Using phasor diagrams, find resultant of: V₁=100∠0°V, V₂=150∠60°V, V₃=80∠-45°V. Verify mathematically.

step_by_step.explanation: Draw V₁ 100 units right. From tip, draw V₂ 150 units at 60°. From tip, draw V₃ 80 units at -45°. Resultant from origin to final tip.
Measure length ≈243 units, angle ≈18°. Matches mathematical result.
Diagram shows how individual phasors combine vectorially. The order of addition doesn't affect final resultant.

worked_examples.final_answer: Resultant: 243∠17.6°V. Both mathematical and graphical methods give same result. Demonstrates phasor addition principles.

sections.introduction: Application of phasor diagrams to series AC circuits including RL, RC, and RLC configurations with detailed construction and analysis methods.

key_concept.definition: Series circuit phasors: Common current reference, Voltage phasor addition, Impedance triangle construction, Phase angle determination, Power factor analysis, Voltage triangle relationships, Component voltage relationships, KVL application, Resultant voltage calculation, Power triangle derivation.
key_concept.context: Series circuit phasor analysis provides visual verification of Kirchhoff's Voltage Law and immediate insight into voltage distribution and phase relationships.

image.caption: Phasor diagram applications in series AC circuits

classifications.value: Classification based on circuit components and resulting phasor relationships
classifications.behavior: Different series configurations produce characteristic phasor patterns: RL circuits have voltage triangle with acute angle; RC circuits have voltage triangle with obtuse angle; RLC circuits have voltage triangle that can be acute, right, or obtuse depending on dominance; multiple resistors combine into single resistive phasor; multiple reactances algebraically sum before phasor addition

examples.explanation: Construction methodology for RL circuits using current reference and voltage phasor addition

image.caption: Phasor diagram construction for series RL circuits

examples.explanation: Analysis of RLC circuits showing how reactive phasors oppose and the conditions for resonance

image.caption: Phasor relationships in series RLC circuits

classifications.note: Series circuits: current common reference. Voltage phasors add vectorially. V_R always in phase with I. V_L always leads I by 90°. V_C always lags I by 90°. Impedance triangle similar to voltage triangle. Phase angle = angle between V_total and I. At resonance, V_L and V_C cancel. Power factor = cos(phase angle). Voltage magnitudes: V² = V_R² + (V_L - V_C)².

principles.statement: In series AC circuits, phasor analysis follows systematic principles based on the common current through all components. Construction Methodology: (1) Establish current as the reference phasor along the 0° axis. (2) For each resistor, draw voltage phasor in phase with current. (3) For each inductor, draw voltage phasor leading current by 90°. (4) For each capacitor, draw voltage phasor lagging current by 90°. (5) Vectorially add all voltage phasors to find the source voltage. Key Relationships: The voltage triangle formed by V_R, V_X (net reactive voltage), and V_total geometrically represents the circuit behavior. The phase angle φ between V_total and I satisfies tanφ = V_X/V_R. The impedance triangle is similar to the voltage triangle, with sides R, X, and Z. For series RLC circuits, the net reactive voltage is V_X = V_L - V_C, and the circuit is inductive if V_L > V_C, capacitive if V_C > V_L, and resistive at resonance when V_L = V_C. The power triangle derived from these relationships shows real power P = VIcosφ, reactive power Q = VIsinφ, and apparent power S = VI. Phasor diagrams immediately reveal whether a circuit is predominantly inductive or capacitive, the power factor, and the relative magnitudes of component voltages. This visual approach complements mathematical analysis and provides intuitive understanding of circuit behavior.
principles.application: Construct phasor diagrams for series RL, RC, and RLC circuits. Determine phase angles and power factors graphically. Calculate unknown voltages using phasor addition. Analyze voltage distribution among components. Verify Kirchhoff's Voltage Law in phasor form. Troubleshoot series circuit problems using phasor visualization.
principles.example: Series RLC: R=60Ω, X_L=100Ω, X_C=40Ω, I=2A. V_R=120V (0°), V_L=200V (+90°), V_C=80V (-90°), V_X=200-80=120V (+90°), V_total=√(120²+120²)=169.7V, φ=45°. Diagram shows voltage leading current by 45°, circuit inductive.
principles.analogy: Like a tug-of-war team - the resistor pulls straight ahead (real power), inductors pull to the left (reactive power), capacitors pull to the right (opposite reactive); the net pull direction (phase angle) shows which side is winning and how much effort is effective

image.caption: Phasor relationships in series AC circuits

worked_examples.title: Series RLC Phasor Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A series RLC circuit has R=80Ω, L=0.2H, C=50μF, with 240V, 50Hz source. Construct phasor diagram and find: (a) Current, (b) Component voltages, (c) Phase angle, (d) Power factor.

step_by_step.explanation: I reference at 0°. V_R=240V at 0°. V_L=188.4V at +90°. V_C=191.1V at -90°. V_X=188.4-191.1=-2.7V at -90°. V_total nearly coincides with V_R.
Circuit nearly at resonance (X_L≈X_C). Very small phase angle. High power factor.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) I=3A; (b) V_R=240V, V_L=188.4V, V_C=191.1V; (c) φ=-0.644°; (d) PF=0.9999. Phasor diagram shows circuit nearly resistive at near-resonance condition.

image.caption: Phasor analysis of series RLC circuit

worked_examples.title: Complex Series Circuit Phasors
worked_examples.problem: Series circuit: R₁=30Ω, R₂=20Ω, L=0.1H, C=100μF, with 120V, 100Hz. Construct phasor diagram and analyze.

step_by_step.explanation: I reference at 0°. V_R1=52.5V at 0°. V_R2=35V at 0° (combined V_R=87.5V). V_L=110V at +90°. V_C=27.8V at -90°. Net V_X=110-27.8=82.2V at +90°. V_total=√(87.5²+82.2²)=120V.
Circuit inductive (V_L > V_C). Voltage leads current by 43.2°. Moderate power factor.

worked_examples.final_answer: I=1.75A, V_R1=52.5V, V_R2=35V, V_L=110V, V_C=27.8V, φ=43.2°, PF=0.728. Phasor diagram shows inductive characteristic with significant phase shift.

image.caption: Phasor analysis of complex series circuit

sections.section_title: 3. Parallel Circuit and Power Phasor Analysis
sections.introduction: Application of phasor diagrams to parallel AC circuits and power analysis, including admittance triangles, current phasors, and power factor correction.

key_concept.definition: Parallel circuit phasors: Common voltage reference, Current phasor addition, Admittance triangle construction, Power triangle analysis, Power factor correction, Reactive compensation, Current division, Complex power representation, Apparent power determination, Power factor improvement.
key_concept.context: Parallel circuit phasor analysis and power phasors provide essential tools for understanding current distribution, power flow, and power factor correction in practical AC systems.

image.alt: Parallel circuit and power phasor analysis
image.caption: Phasor applications in parallel circuits and power analysis

classifications.value: Classification based on analysis type and application purpose
classifications.behavior: Different parallel configurations exhibit characteristic phasor patterns: parallel circuits use voltage reference; current phasors add vectorially; admittance triangles relate conductance and susceptance; power triangles show real, reactive, and apparent power relationships; power factor correction involves adding compensating phasors; complex power phasors combine real and reactive components

examples.explanation: Construction of current phasor diagrams for parallel circuits using common voltage reference

image.caption: Current phasor relationships in parallel circuits

examples.explanation: Development of power phasor diagrams showing real, reactive, and apparent power relationships

image.caption: Construction and interpretation of power triangles

classifications.note: Parallel circuits: voltage common reference. Current phasors add vectorially. I_R in phase with V. I_L lags V by 90°. I_C leads V by 90°. Admittance triangle similar to current triangle. Power triangle: P horizontal, Q vertical, S hypotenuse. Power factor correction adds capacitive current to cancel inductive current. Complex power S = P + jQ. Apparent power |S| = √(P²+Q²).

principles.principle: Parallel Circuit and Power Phasor Analysis
principles.statement: Parallel AC circuit analysis uses voltage as the common reference phasor, with current phasors representing the individual branch currents. Construction Methodology: (1) Establish source voltage as the reference phasor along the 0° axis. (2) For resistive branches, draw current phasor in phase with voltage. (3) For inductive branches, draw current phasor lagging voltage by 90°. (4) For capacitive branches, draw current phasor leading voltage by 90°. (5) Vectorially add all current phasors to find the total current. The current triangle formed by I_R, I_X (net reactive current), and I_total reveals the circuit characteristics. Power Phasor Analysis extends this concept to represent power relationships: The power triangle has real power P along the horizontal axis, reactive power Q along the vertical axis (positive for inductive, negative for capacitive), and apparent power S as the hypotenuse. The phase angle φ between S and P equals the angle between voltage and current. Power Factor Correction uses phasor analysis to determine the compensation needed: For an inductive load drawing current I_L at angle φ, adding a capacitor draws leading current I_C; the compensated current I_comp = I_L + I_C has smaller phase angle φ_comp and higher power factor. The required capacitive current is I_C = I_Lsinφ - I_compsinφ_comp. Phasor diagrams provide immediate visualization of how compensation improves power factor by reducing the phase angle and total current magnitude for the same real power.
principles.application: Construct current phasor diagrams for parallel circuits. Analyze power relationships using power triangles. Design power factor correction circuits. Calculate compensation requirements graphically. Determine apparent power and power factor. Analyze current distribution in parallel networks.
principles.example: Parallel RL: V=120V, R=60Ω, X_L=80Ω. I_R=2A (0°), I_L=1.5A (-90°), I_total=√(2²+1.5²)=2.5A, φ=tan⁻¹(-1.5/2)=-36.9°. Add capacitor with X_C=160Ω: I_C=0.75A (+90°), net I_X=-1.5+0.75=-0.75A, I_comp=√(2²+0.75²)=2.14A, φ_comp=tan⁻¹(-0.75/2)=-20.6°. Power factor improves from 0.8 to 0.94.
principles.analogy: Like a river with multiple channels - the main flow (total current) depends on how much goes through each channel (branch currents); power factor correction is like adding a channel that counteracts wasteful sideways flow (reactive current), making the main flow more direct and efficient

image.caption: Phasor analysis of parallel circuits and power relationships

worked_examples.title: Parallel RLC Current Phasor Analysis
worked_examples.problem: Parallel circuit: R=40Ω, L=0.1H, C=50μF, with 200V, 100Hz. Construct current phasor diagram and find: (a) Branch currents, (b) Total current, (c) Phase angle, (d) Power factor.

step_by_step.explanation: V reference at 0°. I_R=5A at 0°. I_L=3.18A at -90°. I_C=6.29A at +90°. Net I_X=3.11A at +90°. I_total=5.89A at +31.9°.
Circuit capacitive (I_C > I_L). Current leads voltage by 31.9°. Good power factor.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) I_R=5A, I_L=3.18A, I_C=6.29A; (b) I_total=5.89A; (c) φ=31.9°; (d) PF=0.849. Phasor diagram shows capacitive characteristic with current leading voltage.

image.caption: Current phasor analysis of parallel RLC circuit

worked_examples.title: Power Factor Correction Using Phasors
worked_examples.problem: A 10kW load operates at 240V, 60Hz with 0.7 lagging power factor. Using phasor diagrams, design power factor correction to 0.95 lagging. Find: (a) Original current, (b) Required capacitive current, (c) Capacitance value.
worked_examples.final_answer: (a) I_orig=59.54A; (b) I_C=28.79A; (c) C=318μF. Phasor diagram shows how capacitive current reduces phase angle from 45.6° to 21.6°, improving power factor from 0.7 to 0.93.

image.caption: Phasor analysis of power factor correction

common_misconceptions: Believing phasor length represents instantaneous value
Confusing phase angle with time delay
Thinking all phasors rotate at different speeds
Believing phasor diagrams only work for sine waves
Confusing voltage and current phasor references
summary: Phasor diagrams provide visual representation of AC quantities as rotating vectors, with length representing magnitude and angle representing phase. Series circuits use current reference with voltage phasors adding vectorially. Parallel circuits use voltage reference with current phasors adding vectorially. The impedance triangle (R, X, Z) relates to the voltage triangle in series circuits. The admittance triangle (G, B, Y) relates to the current triangle in parallel circuits. Power triangles (P, Q, S) show real, reactive, and apparent power relationships. Phasor analysis enables graphical solution of AC circuits, power factor determination, and design of power factor correction. Construction follows systematic methods with appropriate reference selection and accounts for characteristic phase relationships: resistors in phase, inductors leading by 90°, capacitors lagging by 90°. Phasor diagrams complement mathematical analysis and provide intuitive understanding of AC circuit behavior.
